results.adx_keywords: Capitol Building (Washington, DC);Comedy and Humor;Television;CBS Corporation;United States Capitol Police
results.byline: By Vimal Patel and Mike Ives
results.title: ‘Late Show’ Production Team Arrested at U.S. Capitol While Filming Television Stunt
results.abstract: The production team members had been recording interviews at the Capitol building for a comedy segment on “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert.” They were charged with unlawful entry.

media.caption: The actor and comedian Robert Smigel performs as Triumph the Insult Comic Dog at the Capitol on Thursday, before members of the “Late Show With Stephen Colbert” were arrested as part of an apparent stunt there.
media.copyright: Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images

results.adx_keywords: Presidential Election of 2020;United States Politics and Government;Rumors and Misinformation;Voter Fraud (Election Fraud);Trump, Donald J;Pence, Mike;House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack;Republican Party
results.title: A Day After a Portrait of Pence in Danger, Trump Attacks Him Again
results.abstract: In a speech, Donald J. Trump was undeterred by the Jan. 6 House committee’s account of how his rioting supporters menaced the vice president, and the panel’s dismantling of many of his election lies.
org_facet: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack

media.caption: In a speech on Friday in Nashville, former President Donald J. Trump continued to attack his former vice president for not blocking the certification of his 2020 defeat, even though doing so would have been illegal.
media.copyright: Mark Humphrey/Associated Press

results.adx_keywords: Bicycles and Bicycling;United States Politics and Government;Biden, Joseph R Jr;Rehoboth Beach (Del)
results.title: Biden Takes Tumble During Bike Ride in Delaware
results.abstract: The president did not need medical attention after he fell off his bike at a state park near his vacation home in Rehoboth Beach, according to the White House.

media.caption: President Biden after falling off his bike at Cape Henlopen State Park in Delaware. He and the first lady were spending the weekend at their vacation home in Rehoboth Beach.
media.copyright: Sarah Silbiger for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Euthanasia and Assisted Suicide;Law and Legislation;Politics and Government;Legislatures and Parliaments;Paralysis;Francis;Roman Catholic Church;Italy
results.title: Man Paralyzed 12 Years Ago Becomes Italy’s First Assisted Suicide
results.abstract: The man, Federico Carboni, overcame a series of legal and bureaucratic challenges before ending his life.

media.caption: On Thursday, Federico Carboni ended his life, becoming Italy’s first legal assisted suicide. Left, Marco Cappato, treasurer of the Luca Coscioni Association, a right-to-die advocacy group, spoke at a rally
media.copyright: Luca Coscioni Association

results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Obituaries);News and News Media;Politics and Government;United States Politics and Government;Television;Shields, Mark;Public Broadcasting Service
results.title: Mark Shields, TV Pundit Known for His Sharp Wit, Dies at 85
results.abstract: A former campaign strategist, he became a fixture in American political journalism and punditry and was seen on “PBS NewsHour” for 33 years.

media.caption: The political commentator Mark Shields at his home in Chevy Chase, Md., in 2020. Politics had loomed large for him since he was a boy.
media.copyright: Valerie Plesch for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Social Media;Rap and Hip-Hop;Content Type: Personal Profile;Documentary Films and Programs;Theroux, Louis (1970- )
results.title: How Louis Theroux Became a ‘Jiggle Jiggle’ Sensation at Age 52
results.abstract: Decades into his career, the British American journalist has an unlikely TikTok hit that could be the song of the summer. “I am not trying to make it as a rapper,” he says.

media.caption: His money doesn’t jiggle jiggle. It folds. The documentary filmmaker (and rapper?) Louis Theroux at his home in London.
media.copyright: Alexander Coggin for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Holidays and Special Occasions;Juneteenth;States (US);Law and Legislation;Black People;Budgets and Budgeting
results.title: Juneteenth Is a Federal Holiday, but in Most States It’s Still Not a Day Off
results.abstract: One year after President Biden made Juneteenth a federal holiday, more than 30 states have not authorized the funding that would allow for state employees to take the day off.

media.caption: Juneteenth celebrations in Brooklyn. New York is one of the states that gave state employees paid time off to commemorate the day last year.
media.copyright: Laylah Amatullah Barrayn for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Fatalities);Traffic Accidents and Safety;Automobile Racing;Bowyer, Clint;Missouri
results.title: Clint Bowyer, Former NASCAR Driver, Involved in Fatal Car Accident
results.abstract: Mr. Bowyer, now a Fox Sports analyst, called 911 and showed no sign of impairment after striking a woman with his car on a Missouri highway on June 5, the authorities said.

media.caption: Clint Bowyer in 2019. The authorities in Lake Ozark, Mo., said he showed no sign of impairment after he had struck and killed a woman who was walking on a divided highway on June 5.
media.copyright: Terry Renna/Associated Press

results.adx_keywords: Quarantine (Life and Culture);Sleep;Content Type: Service;Melatonin (Hormone);Dreams;Insomnia;Psychology and Psychologists;Anxiety and Stress;Sedatives;Drugs (Pharmaceuticals);Jet Lag
results.title: Melatonin Isn’t a Sleeping Pill. Here’s How to Use It.
results.abstract: The “vampire hormone” can act like a dose of sunset, tricking your body into feeling like it’s time to sleep.

media.copyright: Dadu Shin

results.adx_keywords: Uvalde, Tex, Shooting (May 24, 2022);Police Department (Uvalde, Tex);Robb Elementary School (Uvalde, Tex);Uvalde (Tex)
results.title: Uvalde Officer Passed Up Shot at Gunman for Fear of Hitting Children
results.abstract: A police officer had a chance to shoot the gunman before he entered a school, according to a chief deputy sheriff. The officer declined to take the shot, fearing injuries to others.

media.caption: A makeshift memorial after a shooting at Robb Elementary School in Uvalde, Texas, that left 19 children and two adults dead.
media.copyright: Callaghan O'Hare for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Coronavirus (2019-nCoV);Vaccination and Immunization;Children and Childhood;DeSantis, Ron;Florida
results.title: After public pressure, Florida allows pediatricians to order vaccines for very young children.
results.abstract: Unlike the other 49 states and the District of Columbia, Florida did not allow health care providers to preorder the vaccines ahead of the federal government’s June 14 deadline.

media.caption: A mobile pediatric clinic in Miami on Friday.
media.copyright: Saul Martinez for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Rap and Hip-Hop;Drake (Rapper);Abloh, Virgil
results.title: Drake Releases ‘Honestly, Nevermind,’ an LP Dedicated to Virgil Abloh
results.abstract: The rapper’s 14-track seventh studio album came out at midnight, about six hours after it was announced on social media.

media.caption: Fans had been expecting something new from Drake since at least March, when he posted a picture of himself in a recording studio. “Honestly, Nevermind” arrived on Friday.
media.copyright: Amy Sussman/Getty Images

results.byline: By Mike McIntire, Glenn Thrush and Eric Lipton
results.title: Gun Sellers’ Message to Americans: Man Up
results.abstract: The number of firearms in the U.S. is outpacing the country’s population, as an emboldened gun industry and its allies target buyers with rhetoric of fear, machismo and defiance.
org_facet: Moms Demand Action for Gun Sense in America

media.caption: A man raffled off a golden AK-47 at the N.R.A. convention last month in Houston.
media.copyright: Mark Abramson for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Shopping and Retail;Labor and Jobs;Social Media;Workplace Hazards and Violations;Content Type: Personal Profile;audio-neutral-immersive;Dollar General Corp;TikTok (ByteDance)
results.title: How a Dollar General Employee Went Viral on TikTok
results.abstract: Mary Gundel loved managing a store in Tampa, Fla. But when she detailed its challenges on social media, the company — and fellow employees — took notice.

media.caption: Mary Gundel, who managed a Dollar General in Tampa, Fla., created the hashtag #PutInATicket because, she said, that was the company’s response to serious store issues.
media.copyright: Todd Anderson for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Dress Codes;Suits and Litigation (Civil);Civil Rights and Liberties;Discrimination;Charter Schools;Constitution (US);Women and Girls;Burks, Keely;American Civil Liberties Union;Charter Day School (Leland, NC);North Carolina
results.title: Court Sides With Girls Who Sued Over School’s Skirt Requirement
results.abstract: A North Carolina school’s dress code perpetuated “harmful” gender stereotypes and violated the 14th Amendment’s equal protection clause, a U.S. appeals court found.

media.caption: A federal appeals court ruled Tuesday that the Charter Day School in Leland, N.C., was perpetuating gender stereotypes in enforcing a dress code that required girls wear skirts.
media.copyright: Mike Spencer/Wilmington Star-News-USA TODAY NETWORK

results.title: Here’s how long some popular at-home virus test kits actually last, according to the F.D.A.

results.byline: By Anton Troianovski and Adam Satariano
results.title: Putin denounces the U.S. as a fading world power.

results.adx_keywords: Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021);House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
results.title: J. Michael Luttig, a conservative judge, tweeted his analysis that a vice president had no power to alter the election results.
results.abstract: “The only responsibility and power of the Vice President under the Constitution is to faithfully count the electoral college votes as they have been cast,” Judge Luttig wrote.
org_facet: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack

media.caption: J. Michael Luttig, a former federal appeals court judge, said the former vice president could not decide to invalidate election results.
media.copyright: Joe Perry/The Morning News, via Associated Press

results.adx_keywords: Presidential Election of 2020;Storming of the US Capitol (Jan, 2021);United States Politics and Government;Trump, Donald J;Garland, Merrick B;House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack;Justice Department
results.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Maggie Haberman
results.title: Despite Growing Evidence, a Prosecution of Trump Would Face Challenges
results.abstract: As House hearings highlighted testimony that could create more pressure to pursue a criminal case, the former president tried out a defense that strained credulity.
org_facet: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack

media.caption: Former President Donald J. Trump at a rally in Casper, Wyo., last month. If the Justice Department brings a case against him, the prosecution could hinge on the government’s ability to establish his intent.
media.copyright: Natalie Behring for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Polyamory and Non-Monogamous Relationships;Dating and Relationships;Social Media;Facebook Inc
results.title: Non-Monogamy Advocates Ask Facebook to Be More Open
results.abstract: A group supporting those who practice polyamory and other forms of “ethical non-monogamy” want more relationship-status options on Facebook.

media.caption: Although “ethical non-monogamy is nothing new,” according to Brett Chamberlin, the executive director of OPEN, Facebook still lags when it comes to relationship labels.
media.copyright: Getty Images
